repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Local Government Finance and
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Local Government Finance
            and Development (LOGOFIND) Project for Philippines were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the reforms and institution building envisaged under
            LOGOFIND required time and sustained dialogue within
            government. Government of the Philippines (GOP) and the Bank
            will have benefited from phased program, with a series of
            loans funding activities but approved sequentially as
            progress of implementation of reforms are made. Through
            Adaptable Program Loan (APL), adjustments can be made as the
            reforms are carried out, unlike with the regular investment
            lending. In the case of LOGOFIND, the attempt was to
            complete a rather package of reforms that proved to be
            unrealistic given the institutional, economic, and political
            circumstance and the short timeframe for implementation. If
            it were pursued through an APL, the first phase could have
            addressed the institutional and capacity requirements of the
            Municipal Development Fund Office (MDFO) as the implementing
            agency. The succeeding loans could have then covered the
            next phases of MDFO reorganization and transformation into a
            separate entity. In this way, the institutions and agencies
            that are assigned the responsibility for overseeing the
            reform process could also be assisted and strengthened while
            allowing them to implement the reform agenda and they will
            be more prepared to deal with more complex institutional
            reforms requiring actions like creation of municipal
            financial entities.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - LGU Finance Development
            Project : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Philippines LGU Finance Development Project includes a
            component providing an engineered sanitary landfill to local
            governments as demonstration subprojects. This report
            anticipates likely negative environmental impacts connected
            to the development of integrated waste management
            facilities, and proposes measures to mitigate them. They
            include the following: To offset negative visual effects
            from the change in landscape character, provide vegetative
            cover on closed portions of the landfill and convert land to
            area to be used for recreation or low intensity agriculture,
            service roads, ditches, ponds, and wetland areas. Use solid
            perimeter fencing around the construction site, storm water
            management, including surface water drainage control and
            treatment system to reduce leachate generation and flooding,
            and cover slopes with vegetation. To manage impacts
            affecting air quality including odor control, provide daily
            cover, minimize presence of exposed waste material, provide
            fencing, and keep excavated areas wet. Install noise fencing
            at sensitive sites, use machinery that suppresses noise,
            avoid nighttime work, and use mobile noise barriers. To
            relieve traffic congestion, direct traffic during heavy
            periods. Protect large trees, transplant smaller trees, and
            provide indigenous vegetation.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Local Government Finance and
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Local Government Finance and
            Development Project for the Philippines assists
            participating local government units (LGUs) in expanding and
            upgrading their basic infrastructure, services, and
            facilities and in strengthening their capacities in
            municipal governance, investment planning, revenue
            generation, and project development and implementation. It
            also enhances capabilities at the national level to provide
            technical support and long-term financing to local
            governments through the Municipal Development Fund (MDF).
            The project has four components. The LGU subprojects
            component expands, repairs, and improves basic
            infrastructure, social and environmental services and
            facilities. The second component provides LGU training and
            capacity building for 1) subproject development and
            implementation; 2) municipal planning, finances, and
            management; 3) improved training modules and delivery
            mechanisms; and 4) piloting of new programs including
            distance learning; LGU twinning; and collaboration with
            local governments, nongovernmental organizations, and the
            private sector. The third component supports LGU resource
            mobilization and monitoring the real property tax
            administration program; 2) new initiatives to improve
            creditworthiness and revenue generation; and 3) developing
            and implementing systems to improve monitoring of fiscal
            performance and local financial reporting and disclosure.
            The final component supports the MDF's reorganization
            and strenghtening.
